p: Moving to the design of agents active in tuberculosis (TB) infection, Venugopala et al. explore the functionalization of the triazole nucleus and its impact on anti-TB activity [ 6]. Selected derivatives were validated against H37Rv and MDR strains of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB). Molecular docking and molecular dynamic (MD) simulation conducted for the most promising compounds identified Î²-ketoacyl ACP synthase I (KasA) as the potential cellular target of the detected anti-TB activity. The results can support further hit-to-lead development of triazolyl anti-TB agents with improved potency and selectivity.
